descriptionProfile: The Universe, as we know it.
The Universe, as we know it.

posts.description: That's a lot of caviar for one fish! Actually, this is a male mouthbrooding jawfish that is doing its part to incubate fertilized eggs...in its mouth. During the incubation process and up until the eggs hatch, the male fish cannot eat. GROSS OR AWESOME? Sound off in the comments!

YUP, that is a snake scarfing down a live mouse. But it happens naturally (sorry, not sorry). Did you know snakes can consume prey up to three times larger than the diameter of their mouths by unhinging their jaws, and trap them in there with their rear-facing teeth? As if you needed another reason to be thankful you’re not a mouse…

This deer looks like it’s taken a few camouflage notes from some hunters! Did you know, during the fall mating season for red deer, the stags will rub their heads against the ground to swell up their neck muscles — no steroids required! In the process, they pick up some decorative leafing and twigs with their horns, that form into rather pastoral crowns. All natural. Photo cred: Luke Millard

WANNA GO TO SPACE?! Well, check out what NASA released... Mars recruitment posters encouraging people to apply for future missions! Although the first manned missioned to Mars is still a few years away, NASA is already looking for people who would be interested in traveling to the Red Planet. Recently, NASA released eight, retro-style posters recruiting explorers, farmers, surveyors, technicians and teachers. All of the posters are currently available for free download on NASA’s website. “Have you ever asked the question, what is out there? So have we!” one poster caption reads. “That curiosity leads us to explore new places like Mars and its moons, Phobos and Deimos. Just what lies beyond the next valley, canyon, crater or hill is something we want to discover with rovers and with humans one day too.” Shoutout to our friends @Tech for the awesome post!

How very zen. Not only is the praying mantis an expert balancer, it can also turn its neck 180 degrees to scout for prey. Their two compound eyes and three simple eyes also aid in the hunting process. Photo cred: Nordin Seruyan

Sometimes we here at @Science can’t help but share a photo we come across that just looks so…awesomely powerful. Sublime and terrifying, tornadoes can do immense damage in just a few destructive minutes. Like snowflakes, tornadoes are all unique: they each have their own sound, shape, and even color. But you wouldn't want a Christmas made white by one of these calamities. Photo cred: Julian Goforth

Squirrels! Though often so ubiquitous they get overlooked, these little rodents are adorable up close. Did you know that they communicate using noise and scent making, and can also send signals to other squirrels with their tails? Photo cred: @jcnrad

This coming September, NASA will be destroying Cassini, the $3.26 billion spacecraft that was used to explore Saturn. Cassini was launched twenty years ago in 1997, and now that the spacecraft is running low on fuel, NASA is set to destroy it before the spacecraft potentially destroys a nearby moon with possible alien life on it. THAT'S RIGHT... POSSIBLE ALIEN LIFE ON SATURN'S MOON!!! Think about NASA’s $3.26 billion destruction the next time you feel bad about breaking something. Shoutout to our friends @Tech for the post.

It’s a bird! It’s a plane! It’s a pile of sand zoomed in on a microscopic level!!! Rather than simply a lump of tan dirt, sand is actually a compound of hundreds of thousands of different earth-like materials, all different shapes and colors. Sand can consist of ocean particles, bits of sea creatures scraped off during a swim, and plankton. What’s your favorite beach to pick sand from to throw under a microscope?

What didn't Tesla create? These indoor, mini lightning storms were simulated using a Tesla coil and arcing objects, making conduction out of thin air. When gas-discharges convert to plasma in a continuous stream, you get this. Cool, right? Photo cred: Marc Simon Frei

This is one HOT post! This outpouring is from one of Hawaii's many volcanoes, Kilauea, that's been active continuously since 1983. It shoots lava at fifteen yards an hour, at three thousand degrees Fahrenheit.

Unicorns might not be real, but narwhals are! These medium-sized whales are more akin to carousel unicorns than they are to sea creatures. The narwhal is most recognizable by its extraordinary tusk that's highly sensitive and neuron rich. The tusk is actually an elongated tooth and can grow as long as ten feet. Nice tusks! Photo cred: @PaulNicklen

MY EYES!!! Out of the more than 100,000 species of known fungi, only 71 are bioluminescent, like these glow-in-the-dark babies. The purpose of the light is to attract insects who help disseminate the fungi spores, in ways similar to how bees help flowers pollinate. So yes…we suppose you could say bugs like doing ’shrooms. Photo cred: Lance Aardvaarkau

Never has something that could hurt you so bad looked so good! This gorgeous jellyfish is the bluebottle, and is actually composed of several different organisms called zooids that cooperate to serve different functions. One of those functions might be outstretching the tentacles to catch prey and then gobble it up. AMAZING!! Photo Cred: Matt Smith

Don’t show this to the Double Rainbow Guy! This is not your ordinary rainbow, no no. This is a circumhorizontal arc (a.k.a. “Fire Rainbow), an optical illusion that forms when light from the sun or moon refracts through ice crystals suspended in the air.

This is the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove in Kyoto, Japan. If you’re in the area, take a stroll down the breathtaking path, beset on both sides by staggeringly tall stalks of bamboo. But don’t expect to see too many flowers — it can take bamboo 120 years to ever sprout a bud. 120-year walk through this? Don’t mind if I do!

HOLY SHARK! This is called a bait ball, and sharks and dolphins will corral smaller fishies together into these schools to better chomp down on them. This bait ball is made up of sardines. YUM!!! Salty. Photo cred: Lesley Rochat
